{{Refimprove|date=August 2017}} '''TiE Silicon Valley''' (TiE SV) is the largest and founding chapter of the [[TiE]] brand, a non-profit organization dedicated to fostering entrepreneurship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2009/12/09/obrien-the-influencers-of-silicon-valley-2/|title=O’Brien: The Influencers of Silicon Valley|date=9 December 2009|website=Mercurynews.com|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref> It provides technology entrepreneurs with mentoring services, networking opportunities, startup-related education, funding, and incubating.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/22/idUSnMKWXJQfka+1f8+MKW20141222 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924211722/http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/22/idUSnMKWXJQfka+1f8+MKW20141222 |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }} </ref>
==History== TiE SV was founded in 1992 by a group of successful entrepreneurs, corporate executives, and senior professionals with roots in the South Asian or Indus region and was named TiE for "The Indus Entrepreneurs." It has since moved away from that focus and is open and inclusive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/print-edition/2011/03/18/tie-executive-pushes-new-programs.html?page=all|title=TiE executive pushes new programs|website=Bizjournals.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/print-edition/2013/09/27/building-the-steps-others-will-climb.html?page=all|title=TiE: Meet the men who paved the way for South Asians to write a chapter in Silicon Valley’s success story|website=Bizjournals.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
TiE SV received the 2014 Innovation Catalyst Award by VC Taskforce, which recognizes venture community leaders for being catalysts of innovation and entrepreneurship. Past recipients of this award include female venture capitalist [[Ann Winblad]], the Draper family, and [[Reid Hoffman]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiawest.com/news/business/vc-taskforce-fetes-tie-pentium-chip-designer-vinod-dham/article_0184f596-5adf-11e4-9d37-339691dbb689.html|title=VC Taskforce Fetes TiE, Pentium Chip Designer Vinod Dham|first=News|last=Dispatches|website=Indiawest.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/tie-receive-vc-taskforce-2014-201257766.html|title=TiE to Receive VC Taskforce 2014 Innovation Catalyst Award|website=Finance.yahoo.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
==Organization== TiE SV is a network of general members, Charter Members, and sponsors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realwire.com/releases/Tech-Trailblazers-Awards-welcomes-TiE-Silicon-Valley-and-ask-emerging-markets-startups-to-stand-and-be-counted|title=Tech Trailblazers - Tech Trailblazers Awards welcomes TiE Silicon Valley and ask emerging markets startups to stand and be counted|date=28 August 2012|website=Realwire.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
===Charter Members=== Charter members are successful, veteran entrepreneurs who are looking to give back and assist the next generation of entrepreneurs by offering their time, knowledge, and resources.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mynewsdesk.com/tech-trailblazers/pressreleases/tech-trailblazers-awards-welcomes-tie-silicon-valley-as-industry-supporter-and-ask-startups-from-emerging-markets-to-stand-and-be-counted-788217|title=Tech Trailblazers Awards welcomes TiE Silicon Valley as industry supporter and ask startups from emerging markets to stand and be counted|website=Mynewsdest.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> As of December 2014, TiE SV has more than 300 Charter members.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://inc42.com/buzz/tie-silicon-valley-announces-first-class-billion-dollar-babies-3-startups/?hvid=5l9hLC|title=TiE Silicon Valley Announces Its First Class Of Billion Dollar Babies With 3 Startups |website=inc42.com|accessdate=2017-08-22}}</ref> This membership level is by invitation only. Since inception, this group has created upwards of a quarter trillion dollars of value worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clearstone.com/the-country-is-absolutely-on-the-right-path-vish-mishra-president-tie-silicon-valley/|title=The country is absolutely on the right path: Vish Mishra, President, TiE Silicon Valley « Clearstone Venture Partners|website=Clearstone.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
==Programs== ===TiEcon=== TiEcon is TiE SV's flagship annual conference. Since 2008, more than 4,000 people attend the conference from over 40 countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2008/05/16/tiecon-keeps-growing-despite-economic-crunch/|title=TieCon keeps growing despite economic crunch|date=16 May 2008|website=Venturebeat.com|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref> It is widely considered the world's largest conference for entrepreneurs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/nishacharya/2014/05/22/look-out-silicon-valley-america-is-catching-up/|title=Look Out Silicon Valley...America is Catching Up|first=Nish|last=Acharya|website=Forbes.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> The conference features two full days of networking and programming with thousands of entrepreneurs, venture capitalists, industry executives, and thought leaders.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/technology/1689197/mashery_named_one_of_the_hottest_startups_of_2009/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405154905/http://www.redorbit.com/news/technology/1689197/mashery_named_one_of_the_hottest_startups_of_2009/ |archivedate=2015-04-05 |df= }} </ref>
Each TiEcon, the world's 50 most promising technology startups are honored as the "TiE50." These companies are selected from more than 1,600 companies screened worldwide. As of 2011, 94% of TiE50 companies had been funded, attracted over $20 billion in investments, and 42 of the companies exited. At TiEcon 2011, [[Cloudera]], the leading provider of Apache Hadoop-based data management software and services, was announced as a TiE50 winner in the software/cloud computing category.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cloudera.com/content/cloudera/en/about/press-center/press-releases/2011/05/13/cloudera-named-among-the-world-s-50-most-promising-startups-by-tie-silicon-valley.html|title=cloudera named among the world s 50 most promising startups by tie silicon valley|website=Cloudera.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
TiEcon was listed by [[Worth Magazine]] in their September 2011 issue to be among the 10 Best Conferences for Ideas and Entrepreneurship.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worth.com/index.php/component/content/article/2-make/2911-10-best-conferences-for-ideas-and-entrepreneurship |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531204210/http://www.worth.com/index.php/component/content/article/2-make/2911-10-best-conferences-for-ideas-and-entrepreneurship |archivedate=2013-05-31 |df= }} </ref>
===TiE Angels=== TiE Angels is an early stage Angel investment group formed in 2010 by Charter Members of TiE SV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://barberacorporatelaw.com/blog/2014/4/2/30-angel-invester-groups-in-california|title=31 Angel Investor Groups in California|website=Barberacorporatelaw.com|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref> There are about 100 investors that invest through TiE Angels.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/12/05/indian-techie-network-bankrolls-start-ups-and-not-just-by-indian-techies/|title=Network of Indian Entrepreneurs Now Backs Start-Ups|first=Somini|last=Sengupta|website=Bits Blog|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> There is no TiE SV fund and individuals invest in their personal capacity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://techcircle.vccircle.com/2011/07/23/india-is-absolutely-on-the-right-path-vish-mishra-president-tie-silicon-valley/|title=The Country Is On The Right Path: Vish Mishra, President, TiE Silicon Valley|date=23 July 2011|website=Techcircle.vccircle.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> TiE Angels was ranked by CB Insights as one of the Top 20 Angel groups in the nation in August 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbinsights.com/blog/top-angel-groups-mosaic/|title=Ranking Angel Investment Groups|date=13 August 2014|website=Cbsinsights.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
Most of TiE Angels investments are under $1 million, with a focus on enterprise solutions that leverage the technological expertise of TiE members. In its first year of existence, TiE Angels invested in 11 companies with a total of about $4.5 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html|title=INDIA INK; Indian 'Angels' Back Start-Ups|first=Somini|last=Sengupta|date=12 December 2011|website=NYTimes.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> CloudVolumes, which was purchased by [[VMware]] in August 2014, was backed by TiE Angels and several individual Angel investors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2014/08/20/vmware-acquires-app-delivery-startup-cloudvolumes.html|title=VMware acquires app delivery startup CloudVolumes|website=Bizjournals.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> TiE Angels also backed CRISI Medical which was acquired by [[BD Medical]] in March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbinsights.com/company/crisi-medical-systems|title=CRISI Medical Systems - CB Insights|website=Cbsinsights.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bd.com/press-details/18508/BD-Acquires-CRISI-Medical-Systems |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404071130/https://www.bd.com/press-details/18508/BD-Acquires-CRISI-Medical-Systems |archivedate=2015-04-04 |df= }} </ref>
===TiE LaunchPad=== TiE LaunchPad is TiE SV's accelerator program for early stage startups. LaunchPad accepts eight companies per batch, and startups are seeded with $50,000 in convertible notes and offered optional working space, infrastructure, and additional support services for a five month duration. Companies also get assistance in fundraising by presenting to TiE's network of investors at a Demo Day at the end of the program. More than 50 Charter members serve as mentors to LaunchPad companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2013/10/21/tie-startup-acclerator-mentors-will-be.html?page=all|title=TiE startup accelerator mentors will be investors, too|website=Bizjournals.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.massinvestordatabase.com/TiE+LaunchPad/investmentfirm.php|title=Company Information|website=Massinvestordatabase.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/tie-silicon-valley-launches-enterprise-start-up-accelerator-tie-launchpad-1843417.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405050334/http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/tie-silicon-valley-launches-enterprise-start-up-accelerator-tie-launchpad-1843417.htm |archivedate=2015-04-05 |df= }} </ref>
===Billion Dollar Babies=== The Billion Dollar Babies Program is an initiative through TiE SV to mentor product companies out of India who are achieving significant domestic traction and wish to scale their products globally.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/small-biz/startups/billion-dollar-babies-why-indian-american-entrepreneurs-are-betting-on-born-in-india-startups/articleshow/45588539.cms?intenttarget=no|title=Billion Dollar Babies: Why Indian-American entrepreneurs are betting on born-in-India startups|date=21 December 2014|newspaper=[[The Economic Times]]}}</ref> It is managed by BV Jagadeesh, Raju Reddy (founder of [[Sierra Atlantic]]), and TiE SV President Venktesh Shukla.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/TiE-in-Silicon-Valley-rolls-out-Billion-Dollar-Babies-to-help-Indian-startups/articleshow/45000681.cms|title=TiE in Silicon Valley rolls out Billion Dollar Babies to help Indian startups |newspaper=[[Times of India]]|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> The pilot round of this program began January 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://in.finance.yahoo.com/news/tie-launches-billion-dollar-babies-155009571.html|title=TiE launches 'billion dollar babies' project for startups|website=In.finance.yahoo.com|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/external/display.jsp?mode=details&id=41981 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610152818/http://www.telegraphindia.com/external/display.jsp?mode=details |archivedate=2016-06-10 |df= }} </ref>

This is a chronological index for the start year for motor vehicle brands (up to 1969). For manufacturers that went on to produce many models, it represents the start date of the whole brand; for the others, it usually represents the date of appearance of the main (perhaps only) model that was produced.
This also gives an idea of what motor vehicles were appearing on the streets in each country around each date (allowing, too, for imports from other countries). Moreover, by showing which models were contemporary, it gives a first indication of how individual designers were being influenced by each other, and a flavor of the entrepreneurial spirit and dynamics of the pioneering days of motor vehicle manufacture.<ref>David Burgess Wise (2000). ''The New Illustrated Encyclopedia of Automobiles'', BookSales Inc, 560pp, {{ISBN|978-0-7858-1106-0}}.</ref><ref name=Beaulieu>{{cite book |last=[[G.N. Georgano]] |first=N. |title=Beaulieu Encyclopedia of the Automobile |year=2000 |publisher=HMSO |location=London |isbn=1-57958-293-1}}</ref>
Within each year, and country of origin, the lists are structured according to the type of vehicle first introduced. These include the following types: steam, electric, [[Hybrid electric vehicle|hybrid electric]], internal-combustion, [[touring car]], [[Roadster (automobile)|roadster]], [[tonneau]], [[Phaeton body|phaeton]], [[cyclecar]], [[light car]], [[voiturette]], [[Runabout (car)|runabout]], [[high wheeler]], [[Buggy (automobile)|buggy]], [[Three-wheeler|tricar]], motor quadricycle, motor tricycle, motorcycle, coach, bus, fire-engine, truck, tractor, racing car, avant-train.

==Veteran era== [[Image:Bollee mancel.jpg|240px|right|thumb|Amédée père designed the ''Mancelle'', which is regarded as the first automobile to be put into series production - 1878]]
===1860=== Thomas Rickett's steam powered car was particularly notable in the history of motor vehicle production in as much that several examples were made, and it was also advertised.
UK. Steam: [[Rickett (car)|Rickett]]
===1861=== USA. Steam: [[Ware Steam Wagon]]
===1873=== The Bollée family played a significant part in the history of motor vehicle manufacture; the father with his steam car, and one of his sons, in 1895, with an internal-combustion engine design.
France. Steam bus: [[Amédée Bollée]]
===1883=== [[Image:1885Benz.jpg|240px|right|thumb|1885 Benz Tri-Car]] France. Steam: [[De Dion-Bouton]] (later internal-combustion, with a patent in 1889)
===1884=== France. Internal-combustion: [[Delamare-Deboutteville]]
===1885=== Karl Benz's vehicle was the first true automobile, entirely designed as such, rather than simply being a motorized stage coach or horse carriage. This is why he was granted his patent, and is regarded as its inventor. His wife and sons became the first true motorists, in 1889, when they took the car out for the specific task of paying a family visit.
Germany. Internal-combustion: [[Benz & Cie.|Benz]]
UK. Internal-combustion: [[Edward Butler (inventor)|Butler]]
Czech. Internal-combustion: [[Laurin & Klement]] (later Skoda)
USA. Electric: [[Armstrong Electric]]
[[Image:Panhard-levassor.jpg|thumb|240px|Panhard-Levassor (1890-1895). This model was the first automobile to circulate in Portugal]]
===1886===
Motorcycle: [[Alexander Leutner & Co.]]
===1887=== UK. Motorcycle: [[New Imperial Motors|New Imperial]]
===1889=== The first Daimler car was a converted carriage, but with innovations that are still adopted today (cushioned engine mountings, fan cooling, finned-radiator water cooling).<ref>P. Roberts (1973). ''A Picture History of the Automobile'', Ward Lock Ltd, London, UK. {{ISBN|0-7063-1301-1}}.</ref>
France. Steam: [[Peugeot]] (later internal-combustion, and the first to be entered in an organised race, albeit for bicycles, [[Paris–Brest–Paris]])
Germany. Internal-combustion: [[Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft|Daimler]] (DMG)
UK. Internal-combustion: [[Santler (car)|Santler]]
USA. Internal-combustion rotary engine: [[Adams-Farwell]]
===1890=== Panhard and Levassor's design of a front-mounted engine established the layout of the majority of cars since then.
France. Internal-combustion: [[Panhard|Panhard-Levassor]]
===1891=== [[File:Buckeye Gasoline Buggy 1891.png|thumb|240px|right|The 1891 Buckeye Gasoline Buggy]] USA. Steam: [[Charles H. Black|Black]]; steam tractor: [[Avery Company|Avery]]; internal-combustion: [[Buckeye gasoline buggy]]
===1893=== France. Electric (and later internal-combustion): [[Jeantaud]]
UK. Steam: [[Straker-Squire]] (also known as Brazil Straker)
USA. Internal-combustion: [[Elmore (automobile)|Elmore]], [[Duryea Motor Wagon Company|Duryea]]
===1894=== France. Internal-combustion: [[Audibert & Lavirotte]], [[Berliet]], [[Delahaye]]
UK. Electric: [[Garrard & Blumfield]]
USA. Electric: [[Electrobat]] [[Image:1894Electrobat.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Morris and Salom in the 1894 Electrobat]]
===1895=== France. Internal-combustion: [[Léon Bollée]], [[Jean-Marie Corre|Corre]], [[Rochet-Schneider]]
UK. Internal-combustion: [[John Henry Knight|Knight]], [[Lanchester Motor Company|Lanchester]]
USA. Electric: [[Morris & Salom]]
USA. Internal-combustion: [[De La Vergne]]
===1896=== In the UK, the [[Locomotives on Highways Act 1896]] replaced the hugely restrictive [[Locomotive Act]]s of 1861, 1865 and 1878 (the so-called ''Red Flag acts'') thereby finally freeing up the automotive industry in the UK (and, incidentally, was also the origin of the celebrations of the first [[London to Brighton Veteran Car Run]]). Knight had been convicted under the old act, the previous year, for not having a man precede his vehicle with a red flag, and Walter Arnold was the first person to be convicted, in January 1896, for exceeding the speed limit. Meanwhile, Serpollet was issued with what was effectively the first driving licence. [[Image:Русский автомобиль.jpg|thumb|right|240px|1896 Yakovlev-Frese]] France. Steam: [[Gardner-Serpollet]]; internal-combustion: [[Adolphe Clément-Bayard#Clément-Gladiator motorcars|Clément-Gladiator]], [[Dalifol]], [[Darracq and Company London|Darracq]], [[Lorraine-Dietrich]], [[Triouleyre]]; voiturette: [[Dalifol & Thomas]], [[Goujon]], [[Léon Bollée Automobiles|Léon Bollée]]; motorcycle: [[Gladiator Cycle Company|Clément and Gladiator]]
Italy. Internal-combustion: [[Enrico Bernardi]]

UK. Steam: [[Leyland Motors|Leyland]]; internal-combustion: [[Anglo-French (automobile)|Anglo-French]], [[Arnold (automobile)|Arnold]], [[Arrol-Johnston]], [[Atkinson and Philipson (automobile)|Atkinson and Philipson]]; motorcycle: [[Excelsior Motor Company|Excelsior]], motor tricycle: [[Ariel (vehicle)|Ariel]]
USA. Internal-combustion: [[Altham (car)|Altham]], [[Black (automobile)|Black]], Electric & internal-combustion: [[Brewster & Co.|Brewster]], [[Haynes-Apperson]]
===1897=== [[File:Winton auto ad car-1898.jpg|240px|right|thumb|Winton Motor Carriage Company First Auto Ad]] France. Steam: [[Montier & Gillet]]; electric: [[Krieger Company of Electric Vehicles|Krieger]]; internal-combustion: [[Grivel (car)|Grivel]], [[Juzan]], [[Société Parisienne]], [[Mors (automobile)|Mors]]; voiturette: [[Decauville automobile|Decauville]], [[Georges Richard|Richard]]; avant-train: [[Amiot (car manufacturer)|Amiot]]
UK. Steam: [[Toward & Philipson]]; Electric: [[Bushbury Electric]], [[Neale (electric car)|Neale]]; electric phaeton: [[Electric Motive Power]]; internal-combustion: [[Belsize Motors|Belsize]]; bus: [[Thomas Harrington Ltd|Thomas Harrington]]
